Python API¶

Models¶

class Model(obs_data, num_samples, param_mins, param_maxs, ctrl_data=None, obs_names=None, ctrl_names=None, inv_obs_weight=None, param_data=None, param_names=None, sim_data=None, callback=None, sigma_max=1000000.0)¶

Bases: object

This is a base class which is used to call a user defined model.

It contains the Parameters and the Observations classes.

The number of samples, parameters and observations should be set first.

Initialize a Model like this:

class MyModel(Model):
    parameters = Parameters(
        names=["k", "t"],
        mins=[100, 0.1],
        maxs=[300, 10],
    )
    observations = Observations(
        data=[100, 200, 300], ctrl=[-0.1, -0.2, -0.3], names=["F"], ctrl_name=["x"]
    )
    num_samples = 10

    def __init__(self):
        self.parameters.generate_halton(self.num_samples)
obs_weight
def run(self):

# for each parameter calculate the spring force data = []

for params in self.parameters.data:

F = params[0]*params[1]*self.observations.ctrl data.append(np.array(F,ndmin=2))

self.data = np.array(data)

Parameters:

  • obs_data (ndarray) –

  • num_samples (int) –

  • param_mins (List) –

  • param_maxs (List) –

  • ctrl_data (ndarray) –

  • obs_names (List[str]) –

  • ctrl_names (List[str]) –

  • inv_obs_weight (List[float]) –

  • param_data (ndarray) –

  • param_names (List[str]) –

  • sim_data (ndarray) –

  • callback (Callable) –

  • sigma_max (float) –

ctrl_data¶

Control data (num_control,num_steps)

alias of ndarray

classmethod from_dict(obj)¶

The class can also be initialized using a dictionary style.

Parameters:

  • cls (Type[Model]) – The Parameters class referenced to itself.

  • obj (dict) – Dictionary containing the input parameters to the object.

Return type:

Type[Model]

Returns:

An initialized Parameters object

Example usage:

parameters = Parameters.from_dict({
    "names": ["E", "Eta", "Psi"],
    "mins": [1e6,0.05,7.],
    "maxs": [4e7,1.0,13.],
})
generate_params_halton()¶

Generate a Halton table of the parameters.

Parameters:

num_samples – number of simulations

run()¶

By default this function calls the callback function. It can be overwritten as well

callback: Callable¶

Callback function

ctrl_names: List[str]¶

Observation control (e.g., axail strain or time)

inv_obs_weight: List[float]¶

Inverse observation weight

num_ctrl: int¶

Number of control data

num_obs: int¶

Number of observations in the dataset

num_params: int¶

Number of parameters

num_samples: int¶

Number of samples (usually specified by user)

num_steps: int¶

Number of steps or sequence size in the dataset

obs_data: ndarray¶

Observation data (e.g., axial stress or volumetric strain) of shape (num_obs,num_steps)

obs_names: List[str]¶

Observation keys

param_data: ndarray¶

Parameter data of shape (num_samples,num_params)

param_maxs: List¶

Maximum number of parameters

param_mins: List¶

Minimum values of the parameters

param_names: List[str]¶

Names of the parameters.

sigma_max: float = 1000000.0¶

Maximum value of the uncertainty

sigma_min: float = 1e-06¶

Minimum value of the uncertainty

sim_data: ndarray¶

Simulation data of shape (num_samples,num_obs,num_steps)

Parameters¶

Observations¶

Iterative Bayesian Filter¶

class IterativeBayesianFilter(inference, sampling, num_samples, ess_tol=0.01, proposal_ibf=None)¶

Bases: object

This class contains the iterative bayesian filter algorithm.

Initialize the module like this:

ibf = IterativeBayesianFilter(
    inference =SequentialMonteCarlo(
        ess_target=0.1, inv_obs_weight=[0.5, 0.25], scale_cov_with_max=True
    ),
    sampling = GaussianMixtureModel(max_num_components=5)
)

# after initialization we have to configure the algorithm to some model (see :class:`.Parameters`)
# this will select an appropriate sigma min and sigma max
ibf.configure(mymodel)

# the data assimilation loop can be run like this
ibf.run_inference(mymodel)
Parameters:

  • inference (Type[SequentialMonteCarlo]) – Sequential Monte Carlo class (SMC)

  • sampling (Type[GaussianMixtureModel]) – Gaussian Mixture Model class (GMM)

  • sigma_max – Initial sigma max (this value gets automatically adjusted), defaults to 1.0e6

  • sigma_min – Initial sigma min (this value gets automatically adjusted), defaults to 1.0e-6

  • ess_tol (float) – Tolarance for the effective sample size to converge, defaults to 1.0e-2

  • num_samples (int) –

  • proposal_ibf (ndarray) –

ess_tol: float = 0.01¶

This a tolarance to which the optimization algorithm converges.

inference¶

The inference class is a member variable of the particle filter which is used to generate the likelihood

alias of Type[SequentialMonteCarlo]

posterior_ibf: ndarray¶

this is the current proposal distribution

sampling¶

The gaussian mixture model class is used to sample the parameters

alias of Type[GaussianMixtureModel]

Sequential Monte Carlo¶

class SequentialMonteCarlo(ess_target, scale_cov_with_max=True)¶

Bases: object

Sequential Monte Carlo (SMC) filter class.

Parameters:

  • ess_target (float) – _description_

  • inv_obs_weight – _description_

  • scale_cov_with_max (bool) – _description_, defaults to True

Example usage:

smc = SequentialMonteCarlo(
    ess_target=0.1, inv_obs_weight=[0.5, 0.25], scale_cov_with_max=True
)

# make sure sigma_guess is not very big or not very small.
# So that the determinant of covariance matrix should be sufficiently small and not zero.
# i.e check sigma_guess for some initialized model.

cov_matrices = smc_cls.get_covariance_matrices(sigma_guess, mymodel)

# initialize proposal_prev or use values from previous iteration
smc = smc.data_assimilation_loop(
    sigma_guess = sigma_guess, proposal_prev= someproposal, model mymodel
)
classmethod from_dict(obj)¶

The class can also be initialized using a dictionary style.

Parameters:

  • cls (Type[SequentialMonteCarlo]) – The SequentialMonteCarlo class referenced to itself.

  • obj (dict) – Dictionary containing the input to the object.

Returns:

An initialized SequentialMonteCarlo object

Example usage:

smc = SequentialMonteCarlo.from_dict({
"data": {"ess_target": 0.2,
    "inv_obs_weight": [0.3,0.7], # a weight per observable
    "scale_cov_with_max": False
})
get_covariance_matrices(sigma_guess, model)¶

Create a diagonal covariance matrix from a given input sigma.

Parameters:

  • sigma_guess (float) – input sigma

  • observations – Observations class

  • load_step – the load step of the simulation, defaults to 0

  • model (Type[Model]) –

Return type:

array

Returns:

a covariance matrix of shape (num_observables, num_observables)

cov_matrices: array¶

Numpy array containing the covariance matricies of shape (num_steps,num_obs,num_obs)

covs: array¶

Numpy array containing covs of (num_steps, num_params)

eff: float¶

The calculated effective sample size

ess_target: float¶

Targete effective sample size.

ips: array¶

Numpy array containing ips of (num_steps, num_params)

likelihoods: array¶

Numpy array containing data for the likelihoods of shape (num_steps, num_samples)

posteriors: array¶

Numpy array containing data for the posteriors of shape (num_steps, num_samples)

scale_cov_with_max: bool = True¶

Flag if the covariance matrix should be scaled with the maximum values of the observations
